contents.context:
Despite warnings from health officials over the coronavirus pandemic, U.S. President Donald Trump is insistent that schools should open in the U.S. this fall.
President Trump argued that the virus has had very little impact on young people.
Trump's comments came after America's top infectious disease expert, Doctor Anthony Fauci, offered a cautious view on reopening schools in the coming semester.
The U.S. has the highest number of COVID-19 cases and deaths in the world.
Reporter : damikim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
U.S. President Donald Trump insists on reopening schools this fall

contents.context:
Some countries in Europe and the U.S. have begun moving towards easing COVID-19 lockdowns and reopening their economies.
However, the WHO warns that relaxing lockdowns without sufficient ability to detect fresh outbreaks could lead to a "vicious cycle" of public health and economic disasters.
Executive Director of the WHO's emergencies program, Mike Ryan, said Wednesday that risks from COVID-19 still remain at (quote) "national, regional and global levels", adding that the virus could in fact never go away.

"This virus may become just another endemic virus in our communities. And this virus may never go away. HIV has not gone away, And I'm not comparing the two diseases, but I think it is important that we be realistic. And I don't think anyone can predict when or if this disease will disappear."

Countries that believe they have passed the peak of infections are gearing up to resume economic activities.
European Union has announced it will gradually open borders, promising to have a tourist season this summer.
London has resumed the normal operation of public transport. and France has also relaxed some restrictions on public life.
Over in the U.S., the country is still grappling with COVID-19 but most states have resumed some economic activities.
Most states have ended their stay-at-home orders, and only a few areas like New York and Washington DC have kept those stay-at-home orders in place.
However, U.S. infectious disease expert Anthony Fauci has warned that reopening the economy could lead to more "little spikes that might turn into outbreaks."
Kim Sungmin, Arirang News
Reporter : smkim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
As countries ease restrictions, WHO warns COVID-19 might never go away

The World Health Organization has warned that easing COVID-19 restrictions and reopening economies too quickly could lead to a "vicious cycle" of economic and health disasters.
The executive director of the WHO's emergencies program, Mike Ryan, said reopening the economy in the presence of a high degree of virus transmission would lead to an acceleration of the virus' spread.
He claimed it's a "false equation" to choose between the economy and public health.

Early easing, reopening of economies could lead to "vicious cycle" of disasters: WHO official

contents.context:
Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell is forecasting the U.S. could face an "extended period of low productivity growth and stagnant incomes" because of the COVID-19 crisis.
He was speaking Wednesday at a webcast event.

"The scope and speed of this downturn are without modern precedent: significantly worse than any recession since World War II. We are seeing a severe decline in economic activity and employment and, already, the job gains of the last decade have been erased."

Powell added the overall policy response has provided a touch of relief and will support the recovery, but longer term concerns remain as there could be "lasting damage" to the U.S. economy.

"A prolonged recession and weak recovery could also discourage business investment and expansion, further limiting the resurgence of jobs as well as the growth of the capital stock and the pace of technological advancement."

U.S. stocks fell immediately following Powell's gloomy outlook.
The Dow Jones shed over 500-points to end at 23,247, while the S&P 500 retraced 1.8 percent.
The NASDAQ closed 1.5 percent lower at 8,863.

According to a survey by the Wall Street Journal, economists believe the U.S. will post economic growth of minus-32-percent in the second quarter, a much larger drop than the roughly minus-5-percent recorded in the first quarter.
But they also believe the American economy will start recovering in the latter half of the year, ultimately recording minus-6.6-percent GDP growth for the whole of 2020.
Oh Jung-hee, Arirang News.
Reporter : jhlucyoh@arirang.com
contents.headline:
U.S. stocks decline after somber outlook by Fed Chair

There have been 102 cases in New York alone so far and around 15 other states are also reporting cases.
Of the cases in New York, 60 percent had COVID-19, while the rest tested positive for its antibodies.
The children are experiencing high fever, skin rash and even toxic shock that means there's an infection in the arteries.

Potential spread of mysterious illness linked to COVID-19 moving through U.S.

contents.context:
While the rest of the international community is still battling the COVID-19 pandemic, the Chinese economy is slowly getting back on its feet.
The Beijing Benz Automotive plant in the Chinese capital, established through a joint venture between Germany's Daimler and Chinese partners, resumed production in mid-February when the virus was still spreading fast throughout the country.
The workers keep 4 or 5 meters of distance between each other, and they wear protective face masks at all times.
Disinfection is also a must.
At the plant, one car is completed every five minutes on average.
While production is not an issue, the factory is concerned about sales.

"But our experiences in April and the recovery that we see in the market is giving us a positive view, of how things will continue to develop in China. Moderately positive. Obviously with a lot of caution, because there're many things need to be managed over the next few months, not only in China but also globally."

SMC China, a joint venture with a Japanese pneumatic engineering company, has slowly but steadily recovered production to pre-pandemic levels.
Since it reopened at the beginning of February, it has supplied components for over 17-thousand face mask production lines in 500 factories across China.

"So far in the global supply chain of SMC, the factory in China has returned to normal state of production and we are playing a role of major global supplier."

The Chinese government allowed factories deemed crucial to supply chains, especially those involved in the supply of medical products, to reopen in early February despite the pandemic.
This shows Beijing's strong commitment to bring China out of the economic slump caused by the pandemic.
It can also be interpreted as Beijing's efforts to maintain foreign investment as the U.S. continues to criticize the Chinese government for its handling of the COVID-19 pandemic at the outset.
Kim Hyo-sun, Arirang News.
Reporter : hyosunee88@gmail.com
contents.headline:
China slowly recovering production while international community still battles COVID-19
Updated: 2020-05-14 09:54:25 KST

contents.context:
Today we begin a weekly series on what the world will look like in the post COVID-19 era.
We've been experiencing a pandemic on a global scale but, so far, countries have failed to come together to address this common enemy.
The response has been strictly national, with many governments strengthening border control and blaming other countries for starting or worsening the pandemic.
This has led to the question: is globalization on its last legs?
Today, I'm joined by John Ralston Saul, Writer of the Collapse of Globalism, Founder and co-Chair of 6 Degrees, the Global Forum for Inclusion, and President Emeritus of PEN International.

In your book, you indicate that a surge in populist sentiment usually follows a time of economic hardship and unresolved social disparities. Recently, there has been much debate over whether the COVID-19 pandemic will end globalization as we know it. I'd like to know your view on this. Do you see divisions between countries worsening over the course of the pandemic?

Are politicians and government leaders taking advantage of the COVID-19 situation and using it as a pretext to deepen existing rivalries and division?

In the past, the rise of nationalism led to the two world wars. If the current trend of anti-globalism sentiment and populist tendencies continues to intensify, what do you think will be the outcome?

The strength of global institutions has also been shaken. The WHO has been widely criticized for its lack of capacity to respond to the coronavirus and for its close links to China. And for the last few years, the World Trade Organisation's rules have been increasingly flouted by member nations. Why have international organisations failed? Are they relevant in this day and age or are they simply dinosaurs of a time gone perfectly highlighting the death of globalization?

You warned 15 years ago that we should have moved onto ideas of social and economic wellbeing that are not dependent on permanently growing trade and consumption. The world hasn't taken heed. What dangers do we face, if we repeat past mistakes and simply try to rebuild what we had?

Should there be a new version of globalization that attempts to overcome the shortcomings of the previous order if you will

How can countries come together to beat this virus and build a better, more sustainable future? Will this take U.S. leadership, or do you see a multipolar world order where nations or blocs of different states balance out their interests?

How do you see the world order being reshaped by tech giants, as their presence continues to encroach on our lives and censor our opinions. Will they govern us and who will govern them?

Well, it's been an absolute pleasure speaking with you Mr. John Ralston Saul. Thank you for joining us from Toronto.
Reporter : osy@arirang.com
contents.headline:
What COVID-19 means for globalization: Canadian award-winning writer John Ralston Saul
Updated: 2020-05-14 05:56:16 KST

contents.context:
Fifteen COVID-19 infections have been reported in China's northeastern Jilin province, raising concerns again, of another outbreak in the country.
The Jilin government has ordered the closure of all but the most essential services in the city of Shulan and instructed its citizens to remain inside.
With the exception of medical and essential workers, all residents are prohibited from leaving their homes.
Just one family member will be allowed out to buy daily necessities.
All bus services in Shulan have been halted.
Taxis are also prohibited from driving into or out of the city and train services are suspended until June 1st.
The measures come as the virus in Shulan has already spread to the nearby Liaoning province.
The original epicenter of COVID-19, Wuhan, has also been locked down again, after six new cases were reported, after the city reported no cases for a month.
Quarantine officials have been dispatched to Wuhan, and have been conducting nucleic acid tests to trace the source.
The Chinese government is concerned the resurgence in infections may again lead to the postponement of the country's largest political event of the year, a meeting of legislative delegates and political advisers known as the 'Two Sessions'.
Lee Seung-jae, Arirang News.
Reporter : seungjae86@gmail.com

Northeastern China, Wuhan hit by new wave of COVID-19

Doctor Anthony Fauci, America's top infectious disease expert, is warning the U.S. could face needless suffering and death if the country opens up too quickly.

"If you do not do an adequate response, we will have the deleterious consequence of more infections and more deaths. And that's the reason why you quoted me, said it quite correctly. Everything you said and I will stand by that if we do not respond in an adequate way when the fall comes, given that it is without a doubt that there will be infections that will be in the community, then we run the risk of having a resurgence."

Testifying remotely at a Senate hearing Tuesday, he conveyed the danger of reopening the country prematurely.
Fauci is one of four top government doctors scheduled to testify remotely at a hearing before the Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee.
His comments come as President Trump has been encouraging states to end the weeks-long closure of major businesses and begin to reopen the American economy.
Meanwhile, Broadway theaters, which lowered their curtains beginning mid-March will remain closed until September 6th.
In a statement Tuesday, the Broadway League said the exact date to resume performances is still yet to be determined, adding all shows are suspended until further notice.
The move comes as social distancing guidelines and stay-at-home orders remain in place in New York City with some parts of the state not reopening until May 15, with the city expected to reopen much later than that.
Kim Hyo-sun, Arirang News.
Reporter : hyosunee88@gmail.com
contents.headline:
Fauci warns U.S. could face 'needless suffering and death' if it reopens prematurely

contents.context:
People are gathering at a military base on the outskirts of Jakarta to receive their daily 1.5 kilogram rations of rice.
To help those worst affected by the COVID-19 outbreak, the Indonesian authorities have rolled out these so-called "rice ATMs".

"I was laid off by my company last week and my husband was laid off too without severance pay. Although the amount of rice is small, it is very helpful in this situation."

The Indonesian government has set up 10 rice dispensers in and around Jakarta, adopting a similar system used in Vietnam.
Those eligible for the free rice include daily wage earners, people who have lost their jobs and the homeless.

"Each day we prepare 1.5 tons of rice for around 1,000 residents. We will continue doing it everyday, without rest, even on weekends, we will distribute non-stop."

Indonesia announced a 25-billion U.S. dollar stimulus package in March to help shoulder the burden caused by COVID-19, pledging money for food supplies and for discounts on electricity tariffs.
Reuters say that more than 14-thousand Indonesians have contracted the virus since March, with a death toll of almost one-thousand.the highest fatality rate in East Asia outside of China.
The media say that Indonesian President, Joko Widodo, is eager to resume economic activity, but critics have pointed out that it's still too early to return to normal.
Yoon Jung-min, Arirang News.
Reporter : yoonjm@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Indonesia installs 'rice ATMs' for people in need amid COVID-19
